div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus | No. 2628 Petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
To the Honorable Judge of the above entitled Court: The petitioners above named, as and for a petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, respectfully represent and allege:

I. That your petitioner, Albert H. Young, is of the age of twenty-six years, and has resided in the United States for more than five years last past, and is now and has been a resident of Seattle, King County, Washington, during said time; that he is an interpreter by profession, and a student of law.

That your petitioner, Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, is of the age of thirty-three yearsl, and has resided in the United States for more than nine years last past; that he is married, has a wife and one child, and they are now residing in the City of Seattle, King County, Washington; that he is now, and for the last six years, has been engaged as a traveling salesman for H.G. Brace & Co., of Seattle, Washington, and is also, by profession, an interpreter.

II. That your petitioners and each of them are unlawfully imprisioned, detained, confined, and restrained of their liberty, by Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, having chargee of the United States Detention Station at Seattle, in the State of Washington, under an alleged, pretended, and illegal warrant for arrest of 1
said aliens, issued and signed by one J.B. Denamore, Acting Secretary of Labor of the Government of the United States, on the 21st day of August, 1913, and an alleged, pretended, and illegal Warrant for Deportation of said Aliens, issued and signed by said J.B. Denamore, Acting Secretary of Labor of the Government of the United States, on the 29th day of November, 1913, which said Warrant for Arrest is in words and figures as follows, to-wit:
"Warrant - Arrest of Alien United States of America U.S. Department of Labor Washington
To Ellis DeBruler, Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Washington, Or to any Immigrant Inspector in the service of the United States.

Whereas, from evidence submitted to me, it appears that the aliens Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, who landed at an unknown port, have been found in the United States in violation of the Act of Congress approved Feburary 20, 1907, amended by the Act approved March 26, 1910, for the following among other reasons:

That the said aliens are unlawfully within the United States in that they have been found assisting, protecting, or promising to protecct from arrest, a prostitute or prostitutes. I, J.B. Denamore, Acting Secretary of Labor, by virtue of the power and authority vested in me by the laws of the United States, do hereby command you to take into custody the said aliens and grant them a hearing to enable them to show cause why they should not be deported in conformity with law.

The expenses of detention hereunder, if necessary, are authorized, payable from the appropriation "Expenses of Regulation Immigration, 1914". Pending further proceedings the aliens may be released from custody upon furnishing satisfactory bond in the sum of $1000.00 each
For so doing, this shall be your sufficient warrant.
Witness my hand this 21st day of August, 1913.
(signed) J.B. Denamore Acting Secretary of Labor" CEB
That said Warrant for Deportation is in words and figures as follows, to-wit:
"Warrant - Deportation of Alien United States of America Department of Commerce and Labor Washington
To Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Wash.

Whereas, from proofs submitted to me, after due hearing before Immigrant Inspector B.A. Hunter, held at Seattle, Wash., I have become satisfied that the alien Albert H. Young, and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, who landed at some unknown port, have been found in the United States in violation of the Act of Congress approved Feburary 20, 1907, amended by the Act approved March 25, 1910, to-wit:

That the said Aliens are unlawfully within the United States in that they have been found assisting a prostitute and protecting, or promising to protect from arrest, a prostitute, and may be deported in acoordance therewith:

I, J.B. Denamore, Acting Secretary of Labor, by virtue of the power and authority vested in me by the laws of the United States, do hereby command you to return the said aliens to Japan, the country whence they came, at the expense of the appropriation "Expense of Regulating Immigration, 1914". You are directed to purchase transportation for the Aliens from Seattle, Wash. to their home in Japan, at the lowested scheduled steerage rate available, payable from the above named appropriation.
For so doing, this shall be your sufficient warrant.
Witness my hand and seal this 29th day of November, 1913.
J.B. Denamore Acting Secretary of Labor" (Seal)

III. That under and by virtue of said Warrant of Arrest and Warrant for Deportation, your petitioners were and now are under arrest and detention by said Commissioner of Immigration, and ordered deported from the United States to Japan all without due and legal process, and in violation of Acxt V of the amendments to the Constitution of U.S. of their full legal rights, in this, that by the terms of said Warrant of Arrest and Warrant of Deportation, 3
your petitioners were and are charged with being "unlawfully within the United States, in that they have been found assisting, protecting or promising to protect from arrest, a prostitute or prostitutes."

IV. Your petitioners further allege that on the 17th day of October, 1913, a pretended hearing was had upon said warrant of Arrest, at the Detention Station in Seattle, aforesaid, before the Commissioner of Immigration there in charge, at which time the said Commissioner of Immigration took the testimony of each of your petitioners, and then toerafter filed, as part of the evidence in said matter, the affidavits of one Hana Saito, one K. Ito, and one K. Uneda, copies of which, marked Exhibits "A", "B", and "C", respectively, and hereto attached and made a part hereof, and afterwards, to-wit, on the 3rd day of November, 1913, said Commissioner further took the affidavit of one Shotaro Washio, a copy of which is hereto attached, marked Exhibit "D", and made a part hereof, and filed the same as a part of the evidence in said matter. But your petitioners allege that the affidavit of Hana Saito was taken in the City of Tacoma, State of Washington, on the 16th day of October, 1913; that each of the affidavits of K. Ito and K. Uneda, were taken in the City of San Francisco, State of California, prior to the issuance of said Warrant of Arrest, and of the arrest and hearing thereon, to-wit, on the 3rd day of June, 1913; that the said affidavit of Shotaro Washio was taken in the Jail of King County, Washington, long after the said hearing of said matter before the Commissioner of Immigration.

Your petitioners allege that neither they, nor their attorney, were given any notice or opportunity to and did not appear at the time and place of the taking of either of said affidavits of Hana Saito, K. Ito, or K. Uneda, and had no opportunity to and did not 4
cross-exmine said witnesses in any manner touching the matters and things purported to be testified to by them in said affidavits; and that at no time were your petitiners ever confronted, face to face, by said affiants, nor did said affiants, at any time, appear in person before your petitioners and testify to any of the matters alleged in said Warrant. Your petitioners further say that at the time of the taxing of the affisavity of said Washio, he was then confined in the County Jail of King County, Washington, under sentence of having violated the white-slavery Act. Counsel for your petitioners was notified and did appear at the time and place of taking said affidavit, but your petitioners, being then confined in said Immigration Station, were not notified and were not given an opportunity to, and did not appear at the taking of said affidavit, nor of being confronted by said affiant at the taking thereof.

V. Your petitioners allege that said Warrant of Arrest and Warrant of deportation, together with said affidavits, are all the proceedings had and held thereunder and taken by the said Government of the United States, in said matter, except, that your petitioners further state that they have been informed and believe the same to betrue, and so allege the same, that the Department of Labor, at Washington D.C., and the Secretary thereof, made and conducted an independent investigation concerning the charges set forth in said Warrant; and received other evidence and communication, and information in addition to that product at said pretended hearing; and that said investigation, information and communication were made without any notice to, or knowledge or a part of these petitioners, and without any opportunity to be present in person to by counsel, or to take part in any manner therein, and your petitioners allege that each of 5
of said Warrants, and all of said proceedings, are illegal, iregular, insufficient, and void, and against the law, for the following reasons, to-wit:

(a) That said Warrant of Arrest is indefinite and uncertain, and fails to charge any specific offense as having been committed by your petitioners, and fails to charge or name the person or persons, or any time, place, state, or location in which the alleged charge of protecting such as prostitute or prostitutes from arrest, or whom, or where, or when, and in what manner your petitioners protected said prostitute or prostitutes from arrest, or promised to so protect, and fails to definitely charge what arrest was then being, or about to be made, and under what authority.

(b) Your petitioners allege that said Warrant for Deportation is in the same manner indefinite and uncertain, and fails to allege what specific offense your petitioners have been found guilty of committing and upon which they have "been found in the United States in violation of the Act of Congress approved Feburary 20, 1907, amended by the Act approved March 26, 1910" and by which "the said Aliens are unlawfully within the United States", in that said Warrant fails to definitely state what prostitute or prostitutes, what time, and at what place your petitioners were found guilty of protecting from arrest, or whom, when, and where they promised to protect such prositute or prostitutes, or what arrest was then being or about to be made.

(c) That neither of said Warrants or said affidavits charge any particular offense against either of these petitioners, or definitely refer to any particular act upon the part of your petitioners amounting to the offense for which they are, in said proceedings, found guilty and ordered arrested and deported. And your petitioners further allege that under their own sworn statements aforesaid, they positively 7
denied having at any time protected or promised to protect, any prostitute or prostitutes, or any arrest, at any of the times referred to in any of said affidavits, being or about to be arrested; and that at said hearing before said Commissioner, they strongly attested their innocence or any such charge, and still now protect their innocence thereof.
(d) That your petitioners have at no time, since their said arrest, had a fair trial or hearing, or any trial or hearing according to law.

VI. Your petitioners allege, that pursuant thereto, said warrant of Arrest and said pretended hearing, and said Warrant of Deportation, they were arrested by the Immigration Authorities at Seattle, and were and now are detained by said Commissioner of Immigration at said Station, and under and by virtue of said Warrant of Deportation, are ordered to be deported from the United States to Japan, on or about the 16th dat of December, 1913, pending which order and deportation, they are now being detained at said station. And that your petitioners are all, as aforesaid, unduly, illegally, and wrongfully imprisioned and detained at said Station, and deprived of their liberty, in violation of their legal rights and of the rules governing such hearings thereunder, for which reason the now bring this, their petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

Wherefore, your petitioners pray that a Writ of Habeas Corpus be, and the same may issue out of and under the Seal of this Honorable Court, directed to the said Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, in and for the United States and the District aforesaid, 7
at the Immigration Station thereof, then and there commanding him, the said Henry M. White, Commissioner as aforesaid, to forthwith bring the bodies of said Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, before this Honorable Court, at such time as the Court may direct, then and there to be dealt with according to law, and to abide such Decree as this Honorable Court may make in the premises.
div1.ab: Albert H. Young Kamasaburo Sugiura Petitioners
R.N. McClelland HAP Myers & Walter L. Johnstone Attorneys for Petitioners
div1.p: Western District of Washington County of King | ss

Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, aliad B.K. Sugiura, being first duly, serverally sworn, deposes and says, each for himself: that he is one of the petitioners in the above and foregoing petition; that he has carefully read the same, knows the contents thereof, and the allegations therein contained are true, except the statements therein averred on information and belief, and as to these, affiants verily believe the same to be true.
Severally subscribed and sworn to before me this 12 day of December, A.D. 1913
div1.ab: Walter AS Tenptone Notary Public residing at Seattle, Washington
div1.p: In the District Court of the United States For the Western District of Washington Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B. K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Filed in the U.S. District Court Western Dist. of Washington Northern Divison Dec 11 1913 Frank L. Crosby, Clerk By EML Deputy
R.W. McClellan, H.A.P. Myers & Walter L. Johnstone Attorney for Petitioners Empire and Leary Buildings Seattle, Washington
J.L. MacDonald Company No. 183
Service of within Petition and recipt of copy admitting this day of December 1913
